Early Access Review

(9.6 / 10) Well worth the eight year wait - Author: archibalduk of EHM The Blue Line

More than eight years after the Eastside Hockey Manager series was put on indefinite hold, the undisputed king of ice hockey management is back. A lot has changed since EHM 2007 was released in September 2006; not least the rise of the likes of Steam and social media. These platforms make niche games cheaper to launch and easier to market. Indeed, Eastside Hockey Manager: Early Access (or EHM:EA for short) is being released exclusively on Steam and is likely to be heavily marketed using platforms such as Twitter and hockey forums such as The Blue Line and HFBoards. Against this background maybe, just maybe, the game will become a more viable project than it was before.

This new iteration is being released as an Early Access game. The game will be continuously developed over the coming months with regular updates being pushed to users via Steam. To call it a beta version would be grossly unfair and inaccurate. The game is highly polished. It’s simply that the game will be developed whilst we play. The thinking behind this approach is to test the waters. If the game generates enough sales then it will return as an annual release. If not, then it won’t.

Full Review -> http://gmgames.org/eastside-hockey-manager-early-access-ehm-ea/review/

Early Access Review

After several hours of playing Eastside Hockey Manager: Early Access Edition I can say that it is one of the most enjoyable and addictive simulation games I have ever played.  I always enjoyed various football (soccer for us in N. America) simulations but I love hockey and am so glad that a game developer has introduced (in this case re-introduced) a simulation for hockey fans.

Pros: The game offers a variety of setting which allow you to establish how many hats you want to wear when managing the team you take over.  You can just manage (draft, develop prospects, sign free-agents, trade players, hire and fire coaches, scouts and other personnel, salary cap) while analyzing endless statistics or micro-manage every aspect of your team by adding coaching responsibilities to your portfolio and establish in-game tactics and select game-day rosters.  The game has an active modding community.  You can download NHL player rosters or other professional league players and team logos for a more realistic experience.

Cons:
- The game could offer higher resolution settings than the 1024 x 768.
-  Also while the lower resolution does not detract from game play I have found that when I quit a game the default      resolution setting on my Windows desktop sometimes reverts to the 1024 x 768 resolution setting that the game uses (from my normal desktop resolution of 1920x 1200). Not a big deal to change resolution back to 1920 x 1200 but a nuisance.
- In rare instances some of the historical statistics do not tally correctly.
-  Some statistics do not export correctly to a file or printer

Game Improvement:
- I would like to see some graphical updates made to the game as some of the 2D graphics seem a little dated like when watching individual games.
- Also would like to see when winning a cup or when a player I manage wins an individual trophy,  it would be nice to have a graphic of a newspaper where headlines highlight the achievement like I have seen in other sports sims.

Recommendation:  The game for an early access product is well developed and if no further development of the game was offered would still represent extremely good value.  There are some small tweaks that need to be made with the game which is to be expected with an early access product.  With that said I can say without hesitation that if you enjoy sports simulation games, you will not regret purchasing this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After an 8-year hiatus, EHM makes its return via early access and while the game is very similar to its most recent iteration, that does not hinder or ruin the experience in any way.  As an early access game, this is a very polished and solid initial effort.

For those who haven't played EHM, the game is a text management sim where you take complete control of a team and attempt to use your skills as a general manager to take your team to glory.  As the game is in early access mode, there are no official licenses or real players.  However, www.ehmtheblueline.com has a very nice roster set, logos, and real team and competition names that provide that.

Unlike NHL by EA Sports, you are the General Manager and do not control the players during games.  You sign free agents, hire coaches, scouts, and of course, trade as you desire.  Additionally, you can set your lines, practices, and tactics.  You also can promote and demote players between minor leagues and choose how to build your team.  As you're unable to control your players directly, tactics are very important in helping you win games.  The games themselves can be viewed via 2d mode where the players appear as dots with the puck, similar to the initial offerings of Football Manager 8 years ago, before it went 3D.


The game engine is solid and provides a decent way to watch games and observe your players.  The minor gripe I do have with the game engine is that it does look dated especially compared with how SI has evolved its Football Manager franchise.  Having said that, the fact that this game was developed as a side project by SI mitigates that gripe somewhat.

The menus are cleaner than EHM 2007 although again, not as intuitive as the newest Football Manager games.  The other issue is that the game can only be run in one resolution which means that newer screen owners will not be able to view the game on a full screen.  Hopefully, that will be addressed in a future update.

If you love Football Manager, Out of the Park Baseball, and text sims, you owe yourself the privilege in checking this game out.  For $14,99, you simply can't go wrong.  The more people that purchase this game, the more likely we will see official licenses and future releases.  If you're an armchair hockey fan who thinks, sleeps, and drinks hockey, you definitely need to check this out.  Disappointed that your team continues to build around a questionable core?  Fix it yourself in EHM.  You won't regret it!

I have just returned to EHM recently because there was so much I missed when I tried to play That Other Hockey Manager. For example, I miss watching the pixel circles run around the ice surface, so I could actually see at least somewhat what my players were doing on ice, and get a sense of personality from them that you just can't get from repetitive text. I missed a tactics layer that made sense and was easy to use (which EHM has), and a trade system that made sense, and an interactive scouting system that made sense, and all the great rosters the guys at the Blue Line keep making. I just missed all that.

It took me a while to figure out a hotfix of my own to get the game running on Windows 10, which is frustrating (I love Steam, I do, but why can't you guys be more like GOG and make the games playable before you sell them to me)... but once I did, I fell in love all over again.

EHM is a game I have played almost more than anything...more than Civ 4 and 5, more than XCom... EHM put me to sleep at night, head nodding over my little laptop in years gone by, because I just couldn't stop until little hours of the morning... and it still gets me that way. I lost a whole morning with the Canucks today trying to decide if the McCann/Virtanen gamble was worth it, or if I should send them back to juniors.... and watching Vrbata miss shot after shot...it was just like real-life Canucks hockey!

So here's to you, EHM, and your amazing creator. I suspect, by the quietness of the updates, that EHM on Steam may not have a long, vibrant life full of changes and improvements (I'm looking at you, more on-ice graphics, because I remember Wayne Gretzky Hockey 2 and 3), like that Other Simulator is getting, but until That Other Simulator figures out how to show on-ice play, and simplifies and streamlines tactics and lines and coaching, I'll be keeping this on my computer and playing it until I fall asleep at the keyboard.

reviewText:
You probably already know if you want EHM or not. If you aren't a hockey fan, and if you don't like pretty deep simulation-based games, there's nothing for you here.
However, if you like those two things, EHM isn't perfect, but it is the best option in the genre. Sports Interactive know what they're doing, and EHM is no different, although it is a little barebones. It's a shame that, for what is ostensibly a new game, there's no modern features such as achievements. Thankfully it does have Workshop support, and it's here we see EHM's trump card.
EHM's modding community is what, for me, pushes the game from standard sports-sim to something engrossing. Real-world rosters and clubs, as well as facepacks, allow for something more realistic - and thus, fun. For me, trying to turn my beloved Calgary Flames from perennial bottom-feeders into an actual force is far more enjoyable than doing it with a fantasy club, with fake players. Without these mods, EHM is pretty sparse.
On its own, EHM is a tough sell. Even with it's fantastic mod support, it caters to a pretty small niche. If that niche includes you, though, you'll be treated to a game that demands time and patience, but yields great reward.

It's gotten much better since Early Access.

Every bug I've ever seen has been patched quickly, every feature I've wanted besides a few have been already put into this game. I don't usually write reviews, but this game is already so good and still has such great potential, coming from a die hard hockey fan, I love this game.
Pros:
Scouting - Scouting mission details can be changed like player age, position, or ignore well known players/prospects, and it really helps you find the players you need, whether you're playing as Arizona stocking up on talent, or Detroit looking for a diamond in the rough, or Montreal and you are looking for some proven foreign skill to boulster your roster for the cup run, you can find the players you need. You can also generalize the scouting by assigning a scout to a continent, or country/nation, or you can assign him to individual leagues, you can even assign a scout to a particular player if you'd like.

Game simulation- You can choose to simply speed up games to get it over with, or you can watch the game real time and make tactical changes, line changes, etc.

One of the best Management games on Steam. This game is an enjoyable experience for anyone who loves sports and likes management games. The 2D Graphics are smooth and easily followable, and the tactics are in-depth and provide a wide range of ways to play each game and develop your team. The game's tutorial is easily followable, but they could use some more added (especially the draft, that had me stumped a bit). The statistics portion allows in-depth analysis of all players in order to create your dream team and lead your team to victory.

On the bad side, each game can somewhat take an overly long amount of time, even playing on fast and very fast speeds. The fast forward speed is what you will use for most games throughout the season. The difficulty is variable and on my first season I was able to win the Stanley Cup. I feel like they should make some new degrees of difficulty and they should allow us to change it (unless I'm missing something and just couldn't find the option)

The game is surprisingly addicting and lovable, and the $20 price tag makes it completely worth it. Easily a better deal than the money-grabbing Football Manager made by the same developer as this game. So far EHM has not dissapointed me and I'm looking forward to more seasons.

Overall I give this game a 9/10 as a lover of management games. If you're not into the Management series of games or if you're looking for a hockey game such as EA's NHL Series, this is NOT FOR YOU. If you do not like this style of game, you could be bored and you may not enjoy it at all.

I've been playing this series since FHM 2005, although it was FHM 2007 that I put in hundreds of hours.  This version of the game is an iterative improvement over FHM 2007.  It appears to be a conservative migration to SI's latest app engine, but maintains a very similar flow to EHM 2007, not the latest Football Manager game.

reviewText: There is so much that I could go on about regarding this game, but I'll try to keep this as short and as sweet as possible. This game is as close to the ideal hockey management sim there has ever been, by a long shot, and that can probably be seen in my hours played lol. The amount of detail and customization available in this game is staggering, and the ability to pick any league/team is refreshing, as taking over junior teams is one of my favourite features. The drafting/scouting system is very well thought out, and even acts like real life, with players falling/rising and teams drafting based on positional needs rather than BPA. Free agency can be a little iffy at points, with many core/superstar players all available at once. The salary cap rises very slowly from year to year, which is another issue, but it's a fun challenge to go along with building a dynasty. Developing prospects requires patience and playing them in the right spots, and it really is rewarding to develop a superstar, or watch a 6th round pick grow into a key player. Trading is good as well, as there will be times where you get 'ripped off' and others where you come off with a steal - asset management is a big thing in this game. The only complaints I have, albeit minor, is that if you draft well, the game gets easy very quickly, as you just trade good players for picks, let them develop, and repeat. As well, if you don't know hockey that well, the game may be a bit tricky to begin with, but the tutorials help with that. Additionally, the custom roster/logo//facepacks that come along with the game are very well done. I would highly recommend this to any hockey fan/sports management fan - 10/10, 2 thumbs up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although early access, EHM:EA is a very polished management simulation. If you enjoy hockey, or any sports gm games, you owe it yourself to pick this game up.


From Version 15.0.1b (first early access version) here are some of my findings on the game:

Pro's:
- Has nearly all the features from the EHM 2007, meaning it already is the deepest hockey sim available.
- Nice new touches like players bio information talking about players close friends on the team.
- Nice tactical improvements like individual strategies for players
-Tactical improvements for lines including choosing who would be the playmaker on the line.
- Free Agency is much more realistic. Don't expect to always build your teams on July 1st, UFA's want money and term just ilke in real life.
-Position's of players are more in-depth, including their roles like defensive defenseman, stay-at-home defensemen, 2-way forward, skilled forward, quick forward. This adds to the fun of building cohesive forward units.
-Tons of international tournaments, take control of your favorite national team and try to build a team to bring glory to your country.
-The in game match view has been improved and is very enjoyable watching your team battle it out.


Con's:
- Interface and menus are very similar to EHM 2007 so it is missing some more modern interface options.
- Resolution needs to be improved for modern pc's
- Scoring has to be balanced a bit more to 2015 scoring levels (its a bit too high at least in NHL games).
- Missing leagues like the Swiss leagues, Russian MHL, and British Hockey leagues from 2007 version.
- Coaches and GMs get fired a little more than in the real world.

There are a few issues like the small window the game runs in and the interface definitely needs some modern touches, but the rest of the cons are minor. The positives far outweigh the negatives with this release. Please do yourself a favor and buy this game if you enjoy the sport of hockey and have ever wanted to build your dream team or test your management skill in the lower leagues and build a legendary story as you climb the ranks to finally leading your national team to world glory.

9.5/10, almost the perfect simulator

I have to say, this is the best hockey simulator out there, by far. This goes way more in-depth than any other hockey GM simulator I have ever played and it is by far the most realistic of any hockey simulators I have played. The strategies mean a lot in this. In my first year of Tampa, Ben Bishop was terrible: 3.43 GAA and a .878 save percentage. I made lots of strategy changes that made more players defensively-minded and it raised Bishop's stats to a 2.75 GAA and a .902 save percentage. In EA's be a GM mode, the strategies mean nothing. You can't decide how a player plays, you can't coach the players, you only assign what lines the players are on and that is it. In EHM, you decide where the player plays, the length of his shifts, his shoot/pass ratio, his practice, almost everything. Overall, it is incredibly addictive. I only have two games on Steam: TF2 and Eastside Hockey Manager. I have played more TF2 than Eastside Hockey Manager, but Eastside Hockey Manager has almost completely gotten me away from NHL 15's GM mode. When you compare the two, EHM is by miles better, and it's still in beta. Bravo to the developers for making such an amazing game.

Wishlist/Gripes:
*The ability to edit players. No matter what simulator I play, there will always be tweeks needed to the rosters. For example, Cam Talbot has worse stats than Robin Lehner in this game which I highly disagree with. In NHL 15 on current gen, you are able to edit players and make the sim even more realistic. I would like to see a player editing option because I still find that there are players who are rated too high or too low.


*More casual options. I think options like injuries, waivers, and an assistant coach rotate goalies option would all be welcome in my opinion. I feel that waivers make it a little too easy and they need some fixes. I have seen the following players in years one, two, or three get placed on waivers:
*Marian Hossa
*Jiri Sekac
*Brandon Saad
*Dustin Brown

If options like this are available then I'm stupid, just saying.


*More simple simulation. I find it frustrating that when I go on a vacation the assistant GM completely takes over. I think there is an option that can turn him off, but it is still very annoying when I'm a cap team and my assistant GM brings in Marian Gaborik. And the coach will also make lineup changes when there is no injury which is annoying. I wish the simulation way more like EA's but at least it isn't a major problem.


*About the injuries, sometimes it feels like the injuries do get way out of hand. I always see like one or two or tears a month and those are four month injuries. I remember on my Edmonton play through in year two I had an injury every other game it felt like. All were minor (thank god), but it got to be very annoying. I think injuries can stay because they add a lot of challenge (like when I lost Jason Demers to a damaged spine which is essentially a year-long injury), but turning down the frequency of the injuries would be welcome.

reviewText:
Game crashed my computer in less than 20min.  And I'm not talking about your standard CTD, this thing fried my operating system requiring a hard power reboot to recover from.  Afterward I removed the game from my system and placed in my steam “Dislike” category.  Just Keep in mind that the following review is after only less than ½ hour of play.  Another thing worthy of note, I've never actually played a game like this before. Wile I'm really not a big sports game fan, I do like statistics and derive a great deal of enjoyment from management sims.

According to this games wiki page, it started as freeware, got picked up by SEGA once it got popular and (much the way of the Frankenstein monster) has exploded out of proportion from there.

Lets start with the good.

1. The Content is Extensive and Comprehensive, and covers data from wide variety of dates, and players from a staggering number of places.

2. Includes Steam Workshop Support.  Thou the content in the workshop is limited, the fact that it is moddable at all is a good sign.

3. The Game derives statistics from a staggering number of categories.  Training schedules, play tactics, talent scouts, fan loyalty, and dozens of other things all factor into the gameplay.

4. Its one of the only sports titles that isn’t made by EA, to me that's a big selling point.

And now the bad.

1. If your like me, and your looking at a good management simulation but know very little about hockey, PASS THIS GAME UP.  The games design assumes anyone that plays this is a hard core hockey fan. If you don't know the game intimately, or play it yourself, none of the information in this game is going to make seance.

2. The game has one of the most dreadful tutorials I have ever seen.  Seriously SEGA, if your reading this, PLEASE watch the extra credits episode “Tutorials 101”
Here
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BCPcn-Q5nKE
Seriously, your a professional game company, you should know better than this.

3. The UI is extremely awkward.  I can see how they wanted to model it after a web browser but its so clunky that combined with the awful tutorial, the experience is unapproachable and unfulfilling.

4. I would like to address any bugs the game has, however since I couldn’t figure out what was going on, the game could have hundreds of bugs or none and I in all fairness wouldn’t know.

All in all, a great idea.  Just not very playable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I supported this title expecting the same level of dedication to quality was one finds in Football Manager (not that FM is without it's issues - but it is a very good game); but this - EHM, is not anything like its sports management brother.

This game is apparently a product from developed back in 2007. And it looks like it. Important features are buried behind menus and different screens and navigating to them is far from intuitive. So your left blindly clicking hoping to find what you need. To make matters worth, some buttons are links without a hover state. So it doesn't look like a button or link, and doesn't behave like one until clicked. I discovered some features this way be accident. You can filter some lists, but I've always found this buggy.

Then there's how data is laid out, which is in a busy, packed manner. Wheres FM lays things out in easy to look at, well spaced datas, organized in a pleasing and logical layout; in EHM you have glaring or just poorly chosen colors that either flash or blend with the games background. And did I mention that to date you're going to play this in windowed mode in a display resolution harkoning back pre-1080p monitors? Yes. This game doesn't know what 16:9 is.

The actual games are laid out on a 2d, with stick-figure hockey sticks glued to little circles. Albeit this is better than OOTPs rendition, but its a laugh-out-loud insult to those who enjoy the live 3d action of FM.

I could go on, but, to end on a positive is the community. There are update rosters and all kinds of nuggets of info to be found at http://www.ehmtheblueline.com/forums/portal.php.

To be fair, to date I've put in 10hrs and aside from the horrific UI - when you get the hang of it I did have fun. But I just find the interfaces learning curve to much work that it sucks all the joy out of what could be a really fun game.

Honestly, if you're a hockey fanatic get this on a massive steam sale. If not, move along.

DISCLAIMER: I want to start out by noting a couple of things that may be relevant to people interesed in this game. First, I never played Football Manager in any form, nor did I play this game's old 2007 iteration. I had no biases coming into this game. Second, while I am a hockey fan (Go Bolts!) I was not a hardcore fan. I was (and largely am) still fairly casual in that I don't follow mundane stats, am not up to date on every player in the league and don't watch every single game.

That being said. This game is fantastic! I am having loads of fun with this gaming experience and as far as I can tell will be having lots of fun for months if not years to come.

Who would like this game?
- anyone who enjoys management games
- anyone who enjoys stats and tactical games
- any sports fans (hockey is a plus!)

PROS:
- addictive gameplay that makes you feel involved and responsible for your teams success and failure
- a one more turn" type of pull (days are done in turns)
- a unique and highly realistic game simulator that you can watch in real time or sped up (highly entertaining)
- HEAPS of potential
date: this game is still in Early Access but it is very fun and playable in it's current state
recommended:
updates will only launch it to new heights
- in depth stats and tactics including fully realized and modeled shot analysis for games (impressive)

CONS:
- confusing and unoptimized UI (needs streamlining)
- can't control players yourself (this should go without saying but some people don't come to grips with this concept until they're in game)
- lack of useful tutorial and helpful tooltips (had to bumble around some things before finding them out myself)
- no sounds except crowd noise (might benefit from certain ambient sounds a calm musical track)

All in all this game as it stands is great and will only continue to get better over time. It's a low price

I honestly wanted to like this game. I love ice hockey and have always wanted to play it, but, growing up in the Bay Area, I wasn't able to, so I had to turn to video games. I couldn't get into EA NHL's Be a GM mode because it quite frankly confused me. >>FAST FORWARD PAST ALL THE SCHEISSE>>. I bought the game, started it up, went to start my career and was very confused when I selected the SJ Sharks for my team, and didn't see any familiar players. So, I naturally questioned what the hell is happening, and I restarted the game to see if there was another mode I missed; there was not. Then, I tried installing something from the Steam Workshop to give me real players to work with; that didn't work either. So, at that point, I said screw it and applied for a refund.
In all seriousness, I can't recommend a hockey game with no player licensing. There's just no point. I had come to expect that from Sports Interactive, since they were able to license so many players and leagues in Football Manager 2016. If you want to see what Sports Interactive is really capable of, save your money and buy Football Manager 2016, it's an overall better game, and considering it came from the same dev, you think they'd put the same amount of time into both projects.

MY REAL REVIEW- 5/10
Everything about this game is fine. All it really needs is player licensing, and it's all fine.
